metadata.titleEn: LessRad Global Surface Longwave Downward Radiation Dataset (5km, hourly, 2002-2022)
metadata.description: Longwave downward radiation (LWDR) is an important driving parameter in climate and hydrological models. Compared to traditional ground-based measurements, remote sensing has unique advantages in estimating global LWDR. There is still much room for improvement of the existing remote sensing LWDR products in terms of accuracy, spatio-temporal resolutions, and the ability to explain and quantify the changes of longwave radiation at various scales. To overcome these limitations, this paper developed a new global LWDR product with improved accuracy (the RMSE < 30 W/m2 over the globe), high temporal resolution (hourly), and spatial resolution (5 km) based on Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) measurements. It serves as a LWDR product within the framework of spatiotemporally seamLess remote sensing dataset for the earth system Radiation budget (referred to as LessRad). As the first long-term high-resolution, spatiotemporally continuous LWDR product (2002-2022, 1 h, 5 km), the LessRad reveals its advantages in studying the spatiotemporal variability of LWDR on finer scales. It also provides a valuable data source for various applications, such as analyzing land-atmosphere interactions and quantifying climate feedback, and thus, is potentially helpful for understanding the earth's energy budget and dynamics.
metadata.instructions: The file is named LessRad_LWDR_YYYYDDD_5km_1hour_v1.nc, where LWDR stands for Surface LongWave Down Radiation, YYYYDDD represents the date (YYYY being the year and DDD indicating the day of the year), 5km indicates a spatial resolution of 5 kilometers, 1hour refers to a time resolution of 1 hour (mean), v1 denotes the first version of the data, and nc signifies that the file is in netCDF4 format. For example, LessRad_LWDR_2002101_5km_1hour_v1.nc represents the LWDR on the 101st day of 2002, measured in W/m². Each file contains 24 hours of downwelling longwave radiation data.  For more detailed descriptions, please refer to the self-description information within the NC data. Usage involves reading the data using programming languages such as ArcGIS, Python, IDL, etc., with the conversion formula: Y = scale_factor * DN + add_offset.  where Y is the real physical quantity, specifically LWDR, DN is the digital quantization value, and scale_factor along with add_offset are the conversion coefficients stored within the nc file.

background: Surface longwave downward radiation (LWDR) is a fundamental component of the surface radiation budget and serves as an important driving parameter in climate and hydrological models. Accurately understanding LWDR is indispensable to the greenhouse effect, the global energy cycle, and climate feedback studies. Compared to traditional ground-based measurements, remote sensing enables wide-scale and periodic coverage of both global and local regions, presenting a promising approach to meet the growing demand for LWDR applications. Although satellite-based LWDR products have been widely applied in various disciplines, their coarse spatial resolutions (≥100 km) and insufficient accuracy make it difficult to detect changes in LWDR at smaller scales. Accurately capturing the diurnal variations of LWDR can provide a deeper understanding of large-scale climate change, and ecological and surface processes.
research objective: To overcome these limitations, this paper developed a new global LWDR product with improved accuracy (RMSE < 30 W m −2 over the globe), high temporal resolution (hourly), and spatial resolution (5 km) based on Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) measurements. With the targeted improvement of our LWDR algorithms, this study intends to generate an all-sky global LWDR product (2002–22, hourly, 5 km) with reliable accuracy based on MODIS measurements.
challenges: However, for current remote sensing missions, as the typical available satellite-derived LWDR product with global coverage and hourly temporal resolution, the Clouds and the Earth’s Radiant Energy System-Synoptic (CERES-SYN) top of atmosphere and surface fluxes and clouds has a low spatial resolution (1° × 1°). There is still much room for improvement of the existing remote sensing LWDR products in terms of accuracy, spatiotemporal resolutions, and the ability to explain and quantify the changes of longwave radiation at various scales. Nevertheless, the daily limited number and time inconsistency of instantaneous observations constrain their application.
methods: In this study, the MOD06_L2/MYD06_L2 products were utilized to estimate the all-sky instantaneous LWDR. The auxiliary data used for estimating instantaneous all-sky LWDR are ERA5 total column water vapor (TCWV) hourly data with a temporal resolution of 0.25°. The validation data were collected from 292 sites distributed worldwide, covering a wide range of geographical regions and climate conditions. First, an improved version of parameterization only based on CTT, ST, and TCWV is employed to generate all-sky instantaneous LWDR. Then, considering the impact of abnormal or missing observations in instantaneous samples, the instantaneous LWDR is upscaled to an hourly scale (or any time scale) using the diurnal variation shape of LWDR from prior knowledge.
dataset: The datasets employed consisted of surface temperature (ST), cloud-top temperature (CTT), and cloud fraction (CF), with a spatial resolution of 5 km. The temporal coverage spans from 2002 to 2022. The auxiliary data used in this study are the ERA5 reanalysis product. The validation data were collected from 292 sites distributed worldwide, covering a wide range of geographical regions and climate conditions.
findings: LessRad reduces the invalid values and uncertainties of temporal upscaling based on limited instantaneous LWDR samples, enabling a more temporally continuous LWDR that is closer to ground observations compared to other products. Compared to ERA5 or CERES, LessRad provides significantly closer LWDR values to ground measurements. LessRad showed a high global performance with an R value of 0.91, an MBE of 5.5 W m−2, and an RMSE of 29.7 W m−2. Validation based on ground measurements revealed that LessRad, CERES, and ERA5 show global RMSE values of 27.8, 30.8, and 29.6 W m−2, respectively. Moreover, not only at the global scale but also in different local regions, such as the Tibetan Plateau, the Arctic, the Antarctic, and midlatitudes, the accuracy of LessRad surpasses that of other products. In dry regions, LWDR is more likely to exhibit greater uncertainty. In addition, LessRad improves the accuracy and shows a noticeable advantage in spatial resolution. With its higher spatial resolution, LessRad facilitates the fine-scale investigation of surface radiation budgets for different land cover types, enabling long-term quantification of climate impacts with exceptional performance. The comprehensive validation reveals that it shows obvious advantages at the regional scales in terms of both accuracy and spatial pattern, demonstrating its better applicability under complex terrain and various climatic conditions.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a technique used to estimate all-sky instantaneous longwave downward radiation (LWDR) in meteorological studies?
Example.Answer: An example of a technique is the use of MOD06_L2/MYD06_L2 products to estimate all-sky instantaneous LWDR. This involves utilizing auxiliary data like ERA5 total column water vapor (TCWV) hourly data with a temporal resolution of 0.25° and employing an improved version of parameterization based on cloud-top temperature (CTT), surface temperature (ST), and TCWV.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in existing remote sensing LWDR products and how is it addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the low spatial resolution of existing products like CERES-SYN, which is typically 1° × 1°. This challenge is addressed by developing new LWDR products with improved accuracy, higher temporal resolution (hourly), and finer spatial resolution (5 km) using MODIS measurements, enabling better detection of diurnal variations and changes in LWDR at smaller scales.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of datasets used for validation in the field of longwave downward radiation studies?
Example.Answer: An example of datasets used for validation includes data collected from 292 sites distributed worldwide, which cover a wide range of geographical regions and climate conditions. These datasets are employed to validate the accuracy of new LWDR products, comparing them against ground measurements and other products like ERA5 and CERES.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'surface longwave downward radiation (LWDR)' in the context of surface radiation budget studies?
Definition.Answer: Surface longwave downward radiation (LWDR) is a fundamental component of the surface radiation budget and serves as an important driving parameter in climate and hydrological models. Accurately understanding LWDR is indispensable to the greenhouse effect, the global energy cycle, and climate feedback studies.

Definition.Question: What does 'all-sky instantaneous LWDR' refer to when discussing remote sensing data collection methods?
Definition.Answer: All-sky instantaneous LWDR refers to the estimation of surface longwave downward radiation under all sky conditions at a specific moment in time, utilizing satellite-based data products such as MOD06_L2/MYD06_L2 to achieve this.

Definition.Question: How is 'upscaling to an hourly scale' defined in the context of data processing for LWDR products?
Definition.Answer: Upscaling to an hourly scale involves taking instantaneous LWDR measurements and adjusting them to represent average values over one-hour intervals, using prior knowledge of diurnal variation shapes to account for any abnormalities or missing observations in instantaneous samples.

Comparison.Question: How does the spatial resolution of LWDR datasets using MODIS measurements compare to those derived from CERES-SYN products?
Comparison.Answer: LWDR datasets using MODIS measurements have a higher spatial resolution of 5 km compared to CERES-SYN products, which typically have a spatial resolution of 1° × 1°.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods between the LWDR product based on MODIS measurements and the ERA5 reanalysis product?
Comparison.Answer: The LWDR product based on MODIS measurements uses satellite-derived surface temperature, cloud-top temperature, and cloud fraction with a 5 km spatial resolution, while the ERA5 reanalysis product provides auxiliary data such as total column water vapor at a temporal resolution of 0.25°.

Comparison.Question: In terms of accuracy and applicability, how does the LessRad dataset compare to other LWDR products like CERES and ERA5 in various geographical regions?
Comparison.Answer: LessRad demonstrates superior accuracy and applicability, showing closer LWDR values to ground measurements with an RMSE of 29.7 W m−2 globally. It surpasses CERES and ERA5, especially in regions like the Tibetan Plateau, the Arctic, and midlatitudes, and is more reliable under complex terrain and various climatic conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in achieving high temporal resolution in global surface longwave downward radiation datasets, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in achieving high temporal resolution include the limited number and time inconsistency of instantaneous observations. Addressing these challenges involves using improved parameterization based on variables like cloud-top temperature and surface temperature, and upscaling instantaneous LWDR to an hourly scale using known diurnal variation patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the current limitations in satellite-based longwave downward radiation (LWDR) products in terms of accuracy and spatial resolution?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations in satellite-based LWDR products are caused by their coarse spatial resolutions, typically equal to or greater than 100 km, and insufficient accuracy, which hinders the detection of changes in LWDR at smaller scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately capture diurnal variations in LWDR using existing remote sensing methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge in accurately capturing diurnal variations in LWDR arises from the daily limited number and time inconsistency of instantaneous observations, which constrain the application of existing remote sensing methods.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of employing a high spatial resolution approach on the ability to analyze surface radiation budgets in various climatic and geographical regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a high spatial resolution approach enhances the ability to analyze surface radiation budgets by facilitating fine-scale investigations across different land cover types and regions. It allows for long-term quantification of climate impacts with improved accuracy, particularly in complex terrains and diverse climatic conditions, such as the Tibetan Plateau, the Arctic, and the midlatitudes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of developing a dataset with higher temporal and spatial resolution for longwave downward radiation measurements globally?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to overcome limitations of existing remote sensing LWDR products that have coarse spatial resolutions and insufficient accuracy, making it difficult to detect changes in LWDR at smaller scales. The higher resolution aims to improve accuracy and enable detailed analysis of surface radiation budgets, climate feedback, and land-atmosphere interactions on a global scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What method can be used to estimate all-sky instantaneous longwave downward radiation (LWDR) using satellite data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To estimate all-sky instantaneous LWDR, the MOD06_L2/MYD06_L2 products can be utilized. An improved version of parameterization based on cloud-top temperature, surface temperature, and total column water vapor is employed. This allows for the generation of all-sky instantaneous LWDR, which is then upscaled to an hourly scale using the diurnal variation shape of LWDR from prior knowledge.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the accuracy and spatial resolution of remote sensing LWDR products be improved for better analysis of surface radiation budgets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Improving accuracy and spatial resolution of remote sensing LWDR products can be achieved by developing new algorithms based on Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) measurements, which result in a global product with an RMSE of less than 30 W/m2, an hourly temporal resolution, and a 5 km spatial resolution. This approach helps in reducing uncertainties and provides a more temporally continuous LWDR that aligns closely with ground observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be implemented to validate LWDR datasets against ground measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To validate LWDR datasets against ground measurements, data should be collected from multiple sites distributed worldwide, covering diverse geographical regions and climate conditions. The dataset can be compared with ground measurements to assess its accuracy, using statistical metrics such as R value, mean bias error (MBE), and root mean square error (RMSE), to evaluate its performance at both global and regional scales.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the development of high-resolution, spatiotemporally seamless datasets for surface longwave downward radiation (LWDR)?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) measurements has enabled the creation of high-resolution, spatiotemporally seamless LWDR datasets. By leveraging MODIS, researchers have improved the accuracy, temporal resolution, and spatial resolution of LWDR data, achieving an RMSE of less than 30 W/m² globally, with an hourly temporal resolution and a 5 km spatial resolution.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of auxiliary reanalysis products enhance the accuracy and reliability of LWDR data collection in various climatic conditions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of ERA5 reanalysis products, specifically the total column water vapor (TCWV) hourly data, plays a crucial role in enhancing the accuracy and reliability of LWDR data collection. This auxiliary data allows for better estimation of all-sky instantaneous LWDR and helps in adjusting for abnormalities or missing observations, ultimately providing a temporally continuous LWDR dataset that aligns more closely with ground observations.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to improve the spatiotemporal resolution and accuracy of remote sensing LWDR datasets, and how can these challenges be overcome?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in improving the spatiotemporal resolution and accuracy of remote sensing LWDR datasets include the limited number and time inconsistency of instantaneous observations, which constrain their application. These challenges can be overcome by developing improved parameterization methods that utilize surface temperature, cloud-top temperature, and total column water vapor, and by upscaling instantaneous LWDR to hourly scales using known diurnal variation patterns, resulting in a more accurate and temporally continuous dataset.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing remote sensing LWDR products struggle to maintain accuracy and spatial resolution across various scales?
Expectation.Answer: Existing remote sensing LWDR products often have coarse spatial resolutions (≥100 km) and insufficient accuracy, making it difficult to detect changes in LWDR at smaller scales. The challenges are compounded by the daily limited number and time inconsistency of instantaneous observations, which constrain their application and ability to explain and quantify changes of longwave radiation at various scales.

Expectation.Question: What are some expected challenges when using MODIS measurements for generating high-resolution LWDR products over a long time span?
Expectation.Answer: Using MODIS measurements to generate high-resolution LWDR products over a long time span may face challenges such as dealing with abnormal or missing observations in instantaneous samples. This requires the upscaling of instantaneous LWDR to an hourly scale using the diurnal variation shape of LWDR from prior knowledge, which can introduce uncertainties and necessitate robust parameterization.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using MODIS measurements for creating a global LWDR dataset with high temporal and spatial resolution?
Judgmental.Answer: Using MODIS measurements is effective for creating a global LWDR dataset with high temporal and spatial resolution. It allows for generating a product with improved accuracy and detailed diurnal variations, overcoming limitations of existing satellite-based products.

Judgmental.Question: How significant is the role of validation data from global sites in improving the accuracy of LWDR datasets, and what strategies could be implemented to enhance this process?
Judgmental.Answer: Validation data from global sites play a crucial role in improving the accuracy of LWDR datasets by providing reliable ground truth for comparison. Strategies to enhance this process could include expanding the network of validation sites and incorporating diverse climate conditions and geographical regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how remote sensing data can achieve such high temporal and spatial resolution for surface longwave downward radiation measurements.
Assertion.Answer: The high temporal and spatial resolution for surface longwave downward radiation measurements is achieved by developing a new global LWDR product based on Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) measurements, which has improved accuracy (RMSE < 30 W/m²), hourly temporal resolution, and 5 km spatial resolution.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methods used to validate the accuracy of longwave downward radiation data obtained from remote sensing.
Assertion.Answer: The accuracy of longwave downward radiation data obtained from remote sensing is validated using data collected from 292 sites distributed worldwide, which cover a wide range of geographical regions and climate conditions. The validation process involves comparing the remote sensing data to ground measurements to assess performance metrics such as RMSE.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how satellite-derived datasets manage to capture diurnal variations in longwave downward radiation.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite-derived datasets capture diurnal variations in longwave downward radiation by upscaling instantaneous LWDR to an hourly scale using the diurnal variation shape from prior knowledge, thus addressing the impact of abnormal or missing observations in instantaneous samples.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used to estimate all-sky instantaneous longwave downward radiation and discuss their effectiveness in this domain.
Request/Directive.Answer: In this domain, MOD06_L2/MYD06_L2 products are used to estimate the all-sky instantaneous LWDR. The auxiliary data for estimating instantaneous all-sky LWDR include ERA5 total column water vapor (TCWV) hourly data. The effectiveness is reflected in the ability to generate an all-sky instantaneous LWDR by employing improved parameterization based on cloud-top temperature (CTT), surface temperature (ST), and TCWV.
